title: 'Royals and Rebels' Review: A Success Story, While It Lasted
summary: The founder of the Sikh Empire had numerous wives and concubines, but the appetite for which he is best remembered is the one for territory.. After I read "Royals and Rebels," an account of the rise and fall of the Sikh Empire by Priya Atwal, I emailed a dozen American friends to ask them to list characteristics they associate with Sikhs. Martial, said most of them of this ethno-religious group from India's Punjab, whose men are distinguished by their turbans and the surname Singh. Others said devout, enterprising, hard-working and uncomplicated. One even listed "big drinkers," tapping into his personal experience as a sales rep with a Sikh colleague in Minnesota. All these attributes-including the last-were abundantly manifest in Ranjit Singh, who founded an empire in 1799 that blazed with startling success in his lifetime only to fizzle out 50 years later, when it was seized by the British from his 10-year-old son.

title: Why Group Chats-and What We Name Them-Are Helping Us Get Through the Pandemic
summary: For many, group texts have become something they look forward to more than ever. Naming them can be an art-here's how to perfect it. Jolie Kerr, a writer in New York City, has a lot of group chats, and they all have one thing in common: She's in charge of the names. "No one else would dare change the name," says Kerr, 44. "They say, 'That's Mom's job,' because they call me Mom" as a nickname. The names Kerr comes up with are rooted in inside jokes, ranging from the innocuous yet mysterious-"Team Nobody Forever"-to more risqué, popular culture-inspired fare like "Mother Earth Has a WAP." That one came about when the group was watching a nature documentary simultaneously, but in their own homes, texting each other, with a reference to Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion's raunchy, chart-topping summer song. The names are "a really easy way to inject some levity into your day," says Kerr.

title: Censorship and Getting Social Media Right
summary: The issue isn't censorship, it's monitoring. Section 230 should provide the tech companies blanket immunity because, they should not even be able to eavesdrop on our private communications.. Regarding your editorial "Twitter's Partisan Censors" (Oct. 16): In the early days of the Republic, we had mail. The post office didn't read it and decide whether what we were telling our friends and family was "true," or decide to "block" a letter that suggested reading a subversive book like "Das Kapital." Around a century later we got the telephone through private companies, but they didn't listen to our calls and block those they disagreed with. In the late 20th century, the spoken word gave way to the written email and text message. The new technologies made it possible for us to communicate with more than one person simultaneously. But now, when the latest technological advances allow us to share our thoughts on a personal webpage or "tweet," everything we say in these private communications is suddenly subject to monitoring and censorship? Are we suddenly living in East Germany circa 1965? Are tech companies the new Stasi? The issue isn't censorship, it's monitoring. Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996 should provide the tech companies blanket immunity because, like the phone companies and mail service that preceded them, they should not even be able to eavesdrop on our private communications. Only law enforcement backed by a warrant should have that power.

title: The Washington Packers May Take the Field

ARLINGTON, Texas-Andrew Friedman endured plenty of criticism throughout his tenure running the Los Angeles Dodgers for refusing to chase the splashiest free agents on the market despite the enormous budget at his disposal. He declined to retain pitchers Zack Greinke and Yu Darvish. He sat out the sweepstakes for sluggers Bryce Harper and Manny Machado. He missed on Gerrit Cole, Stephen Strasburg and Anthony Rendon, as the pressure for the Dodgers to snap their championship drought grew.

title: Martin Amis Writes His 'Last Long Novel'
summary: The 71-year-old British author says his coming work, 'Inside Story,' which blends made-up characters with real-life figures such as Christopher Hitchens and Anna Wintour, will probably be his final big book. Martin Amis calls his new novel, which melds autobiography and fiction, a "baggy monster" because it runs for 560 pages and has many footnotes. "Inside Story," to be published Oct. 27, also reads like a farewell. In his introduction, the 71-year-old British author writes that this is almost certainly his "last long novel." Over his nearly 50-year career, Mr. Amis has published about 25 works of fiction and nonfiction.

title: Nestlé Toughs It Out in the Kitchen
summary: World's biggest food company upgraded its full-year guidance as sales picked up in the third quarter. For household staples companies, it now makes a big difference whether your brands replenish people's pantries or their cleaning supplies. Over time, Nestlé is betting that health concerns take a different turn.

title: The Most Dangerous Thing in Sports: Dinner
summary: Playing football and other sports hasn't resulted in virus transmission so far. A meal with your teammates may be a bigger problem.. The NFL season has been sacked by bursts of Covid-19 cases over the last several weeks. Games have been postponed. Teams have been shut down. Safety protocols have been overhauled.

title: Electric-Vehicle Startups Are Wall Street's Hot New Thing. No Revenue? No Problem.
summary: Boom is fueled by Tesla's stock rise and blank-check companies that take startups public. Early this summer, electric-vehicle startups Hyliion Inc., Fisker Inc. and Lordstown Motors Corp. were tiny companies with staff numbers measuring in the dozens. Two had built little more than a prototype. None have reported any revenue.

title: Airlines Have Rules About Face Masks-That's Not Always Enough
summary: Some passengers are pushing back against the measures that protect against the spread of coronavirus as the number of fliers has started to climb. Covid-19 infections are increasing nationwide, and airplanes are one place where social distancing is all but impossible. Yet resistance to wearing face masks on board may be growing.

title: Netflix, Snap, Slack, Twitter: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: S&P 500 futures are wavering between gains and losses as investors weigh stimulus prospects and a mixed bag of earnings reports. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Wednesday.

title: iPad Air Review: Pro Tablet Features for (a Bit) Less
summary: Apple's new iPad Air with 10.9-inch display is an entry-level iPad Pro that can replace some, but not all, of the functions of your laptop.

title: Fed's Brainard Says More Spending Needed to Avoid Recovery Imbalance
summary: Top central-bank official says asset-purchase plans could be clarified in coming months. A top Federal Reserve official warned that the U.S. economy would face a substandard and uneven recovery without additional government spending to shore up the hardest-hit sectors from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Men's Jeans Are Back, So Suck in Those Guts
summary: During lockdown, men cast stiff jeans aside, relying on looser, lazier sweats and gym shorts. This fall, denim-tweaked to be more comfortable-is worth reaching for again.. IN THE PANDEMIC'S early months, jeans appeared to be down for the count. Stretch-waisted loungewear became the daily uniform for many Americans who were suddenly fielding Zoom calls from home. Unsurprisingly, there was a marked uptick in sales in the men's sweatpants and loungewear categories as we all sheltered in place. People were buying clothes to satisfy their new stay-at-home lifestyles.

title: Brooklyn Home Demand Bounces Back as Buyers Look Beyond Manhattan
summary: Shoppers seeking more space, lower prices have lifted the borough's housing market. Brooklyn's housing market is showing fresh signs of life, boosted by home buyers seeking more space and lower prices than across the river in Manhattan.

title: China Beat Back Covid-19, but at a Cost of Growing Inequality
summary: Resume Subscription. Fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic is widening the gap between haves and have-nots in China, a trend that could bring social tensions and undermine the country's stronger-than-expected economic recovery.

title: Montana Is a Rare State With a Competitive Race for Governor
summary: Democrat Mike Cooney and Republican Greg Gianforte are in a tight election to run the state, though President Trump leads comfortably there.

title: SPACs Will Have a Tough Time Cleaning Up on Renewables
summary: Special purpose acquisition companies are targeting the renewable-energy industry, but there is less of a direct incentive for going public. Investor appetite for sustainable investments and yield have both been huge lately, but there have hardly been any debuts of cash-generating renewable-energy companies recently. Could SPACs, or special purpose acquisition companies, be the answer?

title: Choosing Upholstery Fabric Can Be Paralyzing. Here's How to Break Through.
summary: A self-confessed binge-swatcher-overwhelmed by the fabric options now available to non-decorators-seeks help re-covering a vintage chair. THE OTHER DAY my friend Stephanie found me sitting on the floor dazed and surrounded by dozens of fabric swatches that I had dealt out onto the carpet like a pack of playing cards: gray mohair, linen embroidered with botanical motifs, cottons with colorful ikat patterns.

title: Coronavirus Stimulus Talks Make Progress Despite Resistance
summary: White House, Democrats make progress toward a deal despite resistance from Senate Republicans. WASHINGTON-White House and Democratic negotiators said they would press ahead with efforts to reach a sweeping coronavirus relief deal after making progress Tuesday, even as the prospect of a roughly $2 trillion package sparked opposition from Senate Republicans.

title: Cameo Pitches Its Custom Celebrity Videos for Business-to-Business Marketing
summary: With in-person networking on ice, the company hopes b-to-b sales executives will want to stand out in other ways. Cameo, a company that helps fans hire celebrities from Snoop Dogg to Rosie O'Donnell to record custom videos for birthdays and other occasions, believes it has a new revenue opportunity: pitching its stable of actors, athletes and influencers for business-to-business sales.

title: Rising Interest in Recreational Vehicles Helps Rental Platform Secure Investment
summary: KKR leads investment of more than $100 million in RVshare, an online marketplace connecting RV owners with renters. Private-equity firm KKR & Co. Inc. is spearheading an investment of more than $100 million in a peer-to-peer rental platform for recreational vehicles as the coronavirus pandemic brings new interest to the pastime.

title: Pandemic-Era Shoppers Splurge on Vitamins, Boosting Nestlé Sales
summary: Small health-science division posts double-digit gains as consumers flock to products that boost health. Nestlé SA said the pandemic has increased consumers' health consciousness, boosting its small but fast-growing health-sciences unit and contributing to better-than-expected overall sales at the world's largest packaged-food maker.

title: Pfizer Sets Up Its 'Biggest Ever' Vaccination Distribution Campaign
summary: The U.S. pharmaceutical giant is preparing to ship billions of Covid-19 vaccines using frozen boxes, cargo planes and trucks in a mega logistics operation. In Kalamazoo, Mich., a stretch of land the size of a football field has been turned into a staging ground outfitted with 350 large freezers, ready to take delivery of millions of doses of Covid-19 vaccine before they can be shipped around the world.

title: Financial Firms Gear Up for Biden and an Emboldened Consumer Watchdog
summary: Biden team envisions Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issuing harsher penalties; companies are pushing to resolve pending cases. Lenders are worried the days of a business-friendly Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are numbered.

title: Google Rethinks App Design for Internet Novices
summary: The company's Go apps aim to teach new internet users the web's visual language. Alphabet Inc.'s Google in March unveiled a photography app for smartphones that appeared underwhelmingly basic. But the simplicity was by design.

title: Disjointed Covid-19 Apps Across U.S. Raise Questions About Tech's Role
summary: The lack of a national plan on contact tracing has resulted in a state-by-state patchwork of differing technological tools. Months after a burst of optimism about the potential for technology to help track the spread of Covid-19, a hodgepodge of mobile phone apps around the U.S. has yielded unclear results amid inconsistent policies and usage.

title: Applying for PPP Forgiveness? Here Are Some Things to Know
summary: Borrowers should apply to the bank that originally extended the loan; some lenders haven't started accepting applications. U.S. lenders issued more than five million forgivable loans through the federal government's coronavirus aid initiative for small businesses, the Paycheck Protection Program. The Small Business Administration in August started accepting applications to have the loans forgiven, and it began approving them this month. Here are some things to know.

title: Leveraged Buyouts Come Roaring Back
summary: Private-equity firms return to focus on mounting cash piles following assessment of shutdown damage. The market for leveraged buyouts has sprung back to life after private-equity firms finished triaging their coronavirus-stricken portfolio companies and shifted attention back to their mounting cash piles.

title: Cathay Pacific Slashes Workforce as Travel Forecasts Remain Bleak
summary: Hong Kong's flagship carrier closes subsidiary Cathay Dragon in effort to reduce monthly losses. Hong Kong's flagship carrier, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. , will cut its workforce by a quarter and close a subsidiary airline as it seeks to stem losses from a coronavirus-induced downturn that is expected to devastate the global aviation industry for years to come.

title: Political and Pandemic Turmoil Make for a Noxious Economic Mix in Thailand
summary: Protests in the capital compound economic strain that emerged even before the pandemic devastated the tourism industry. The protests currently rocking Thailand have reached the country's financial markets. The tourism-dependent economy was already more severely affected than most by the pandemic, and there is little reason to be optimistic about a rapid improvement.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
